titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I took Charles to walk with me this Morning, the weather being fine— We met Count Romanzoff who asked me if I had any news from England— He said Mr Lohman had brought him letters from General Van Suchtelen at Stockholm, but he had neglected to send him the English papers— Mr Harris called upon me, and brought me Morning Chronicles to 2 April— I went with Charles and saw the remaining Exhibition at the Gachellies— Tight-rope dancing— Balancing, and slight of hand— In the Evening I walked on the Boulevard; and saw the procession of Carriages round the Squares— They were very numerous; but dispersed very early. The rest of the Evening I was reading the English Papers— I received from Count Romanzoff the Passport for Mr Norman, with a Packet to be sent by him for Mr Daschkoff. The General of the Jesuits brought me a letter for America.

2. Early this morning I received a Notification from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin, that there would be a Te Deum at the Imperial Chapel in the Winter Palace, at Noon; for the occupation of Thorn by the Russian troops. I went with Mr: Smith at half past twelve— The Te Deum began about half past one— It was very thinly attended— The Spanish Minister Bardaxi Azara, and all his legation and Captain Guedes the Portuguese Chargé d’Affairs were absent— They were gone to Czarsko Zelo, where the Oath of Allegiance to Ferdinand the seventh, was administered to a Regiment of Spanish Prisoners taken last Summer, and stationed during the Winter at Czarsko-Zelo. The Ministers of the Allied Courts were all going out to witness the Ceremony, after which they were entertained by the Spanish Minister. After dinner I walked on the Boulevard of the Admiralty, and saw the Procession of Carriages— It was very numerous and the walk was greatly crowded; this being the last of the Easter-Holidays and the Weather fine— I read Prayers before dinner, after returning from the Te Deum; for the second Sunday after Easter; and Sterne’s Sermon upon the Character of St. Peter— It is not among the best, and contains a virulent attack upon the Romish Church— It must have been preached at a Church dedicated to this Saint, and on his day; which is the 29th: of June— In the Evening I read Nothing— Captain Norman called on me, and took part of his Papers— He is to come to-morrow for the remainder— It was seven O’Clock this Morning when I rose—which has not happened before these three Months.

3. I took Charles to walk out with me this Morning.— Captain Norman came for the last of his dispatches; but he has concluded not to go untill to-morrow Morning, and will call again— I finished this Evening my preparations for him— Walking after dinner, I met Mr Calhoun, who told me that he intended to go in about three Weeks to Stockholm, Copenhagen, and Hamburg; offered to take dispatches and asked if I could obtain for him a Courier’s Passport— I promised to make the application— I also met and had some conversation with Mr. Lewis; concerning Mr Redwood’s Hats— I agreed to see or write to Mr Gourieff again about the affair. I received letters from Mr Speyer at Stockholm and Mr Forbes at Copenhagen— Read a few pages of Malthus

4. Captain Norman came and took the remainder of the dispatches which I had prepared for him— He was to take his departure, an hour afterwards— In my Evening walk I saw the Sun set—to rise to-morrow morning precisely at four O’Clock. On returning home I found a Note from Messrs. Meyer and Bruxner, requesting me to sign 4th: and 5th of my last Bills upon Amsterdam—which I did— Played Loto, about half an hour, untill ten; when I finished the Evening. It was scarcely dark.

5. Mrs: Adams is again unwell and was confined the whole day to her bed— With the exception of my Morning and Evening walks, I was employed at home the whole day; very busily but upon small objects— In the morning I walked for the first time this Season in the Summer Garden which is just opened— In the Evening I met Captain Krusenstern, and thanked him for the Copy of his Voyage round the World which he sent me a few days ago. I read several Chapters of Malthus, whose Principle is that the natural
tendency of population is in all states of human society to excess—that is to encroach upon the means of subsistence by which it must in the Nature of things be limited.— He estimates, that wherever the means of subsistence increase in an equal proportion with the population, that the numbers in any given society double every fourteen or fifteen years— He then proceeds to consider the checks upon population existing in the several states of Society. Beginning with the Savages of America, the South-Sea Islands and the African Negroes— He thence proceeds to the Pastoral Nations antient and Modern— I am now in this part of the Book— He classes the checks to Population under three general heads— Moral restraint—Vice—and Misery— And he argues the utter absurdity of all direct encouragements to Population, which he contends can operate only to increase misery— His pictures of the checks upon Population are precise, specific, drawn from the most authentic accounts, and turn the stomach with disgust and horror. I also read Ozanam upon the use of the Compas de Proportion; an instrument which I have possessed these thirty years without ever having understood its use. [symbols]

6: Mr. Theodore Meyer, a native of Germany, and Citizen of the United States called upon me this morning, wishing for Passports to go to Stockholm— He will come again— Mr Harris paid me a morning visit and afterwards sent me the draught of a french Translation of the Report of the Committee of the American House of Representatives, recommending a Declaration of War against Great Britain— The rest of the day and Evening I was engaged in comparing it with the original, and making corrections— After dinner I took Charles to walk with me— Passing by Dr Pitt’s house, I saw Dr: Simpson coming out from it, and enquired how Dr Pitt was— He told me that he was so near his end, that he would not live an hour longer— He died in fact between 8 and 9 this Evening.— His disease was a Typhus fever— This distemper has been very prevalent here, the latter part of this Winter— It appears to be one to which the Country is much subject. Mr Bailey the English Consul came up, while I was speaking with Dr Simpson, and said he had letters from England to 13 April— No News— I left them in Conversation together— Read some pages of Ozanam, and some of Malthus— Mrs Adams continues ill.

7. I finished the examination and correction of the translation this Morning, and called upon Mr Harris with it before Breakfast— He afterwards sent for the Original to have the German Translation made from it— And I accordingly sent it to him. Mr Fisher and Mr Redwood called upon me— Mr Fisher brought me the two Ukazes of the Emperor Paul concerning the Coins, of 20 Jany: and 3. Octr: 1797. which I have been three years endeavouring to procure; and with them he also brought a German Translation— After dinner I took Charles to walk with me in the Summer Gardens, both of which are now open— I began yesterday to give Charles a daily writing lesson, with that of reading and arithmetic— I read Ozanam and Malthus; who is considering the checks to Population in Turkey, Persia, India, Thibet, China and Japan— His fundamental principle is that every where the principle of Population tends to surpass the means of subsistence, and it is very difficult to contest his facts or his inferences— Mr Jefferson once told me he thought them unanswerable.

8. I examined the two Ukazes of the Emperor Paul concerning the Coins, and ascertained what had heretofore occasioned some confusion in my mind, owing to his use of the term Ducat for his gold Coin, which I had not discriminated from the Dutch Ducat— His Ducats were worth five silver Rubles— The Dutch Ducats are less than three— I took Charles out to walk with me before breakfast. Miss Frederica Bode dined with us, and Mr Forbes passed the Evening here, untill near 12— I read further in Ozanam and Malthus— Charles’s lessons are extended almost to three hours— My present employment of leisure time is agreeable, but partakes too much of indolence— Mrs Adams left her chamber again.

9. Mrs Adams was again quite unwell, and Mrs Smith was confined to her chamber— I walked alone morning and Evening. There is yet much ice floating down upon the river from the lake, so that the bridges cannot be replaced. Pierre Ouvre, now my Steward and who has lived with me ever since I have been in this Country, came this day and asked my permission to be married. He is incomparably the best servant I have had in this Country, but this will spoil him. I cannot refuse him the permission he asks, but I must prepare myself to lose him— I read prayers for the third Sunday after Easter, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the 30th: of January.— Also three letters of the Capucin Joseph-Romain Joly on the Geography of the sacred history.— The first is upon the dimensions of Noah’s Ark, the second upon the dwellings of the Patriarchs; and the third upon the road of the Israelites on their going out of Egypt, from Memphis to the Red Sea— If however Memphis was the point of their departure, it is strange that it is never once named in the Bible— I read besides some pages in Malthus, and wrote a few lines only— The weather is very cold, and there was Snow.

10. More snow this morning, and floating ice still upon the river. I received letters from Mr Beasley at London, and from Mr Fosdick at Gothenburg. Mrs: Krehmer dined with us. After dinner I went with Mr Smith to the English Chapel and attended the funeral of Dr Pitt— The service was read by Dr Beresford— Counts Romanzoff and Kotschubey, Prince Galitzin, Mr Kosodavleff, Count Soltykoff, the Archbishop of Mohileff, two or three Russian Priests, and several other Clergymen were there— The service began between 6 and 7 and was over in half an hour. I immediately returned home—read several Chapters of Malthus. The news in the letters I received, gave me no little anxiety—

11. I took Charles to walk with me this morning before breakfast. I had been waiting ten days in the expectation that the Bridge to the Wasili-ostroff would be replaced, untill I could wait no longer without inconvenience— I therefore crossed the river in a Boat, and called upon Mr. Meyer for the business on which I was desirous of seeing him— I afterwards paid a visit to Raimbert whom I found complaining still of the numbness of his limbs; and still resolved to go as soon as he can obtain his Passports to the South of France; his native Country. I dined with Mr Smith at Count Romanzoff’s. No other of the foreign Ministers was there— But it was a dinner to a Baron de Tawast, formerly Swedish Minister at Constantinople, and now an Aid de Camp of the Swedish Prince Royal— The young Count Löwenhielm was there; but neither the Minister, nor Mr Brandel, they being both confined at home by sickness— I called at the Count’s after dinner, but saw neither of them. At dinner I was seated between Count Kotschubey and General Betancourt; with both of whom I had some Conversation— That with the Count was chiefly political; on our War with England— My feelings on this subject and some remarks and Questions of the Count’s urged me to a degree of warmth bordering at least on indiscretion— Count Romanzoff who was unusually marked in his attentions to me, said in a tone of pleasantry; how happens it that you are constantly beating at Sea, the English, who beat all the rest of the World, and that on land, where you ought to be the strongest, the English do what they please. I answered him in the same manner, that I knew not how to account for it, unless by supposing that these times were reserved to keep the world in a continual state of wonder; and to prove that there is something new under the Sun— He replied that there had once been a confusion of tongues, and now he believed was the time for a confusion of minds.— After returning home I walked an hour— Met successively Mr Lewis and Mr J. W. Smith; with each of whom I had conversation.— I found the Bridge at length was being replaced— Mr Harris paid us an Evening visit. Mrs Krehmer, and her daughter, and Countess Colombi with her two Sisters had also paid visits to the Ladies— I received Bills to sign from Messrs: Meyer and Brüxner— Charles lost his lesson this morning.

12. Captain Florence, Master of an American vessel at Cronstadt, called upon me to ask my advice what to do with his vessel, his men, and himself. He cannot attempt to go out in the present state of affairs— He is here at heavy expence, and his means of supporting it will soon be exhausted. I advised him as well as I could, but could suggest to him no eligible means of extricating him from his embarrassment. He finally concluded to take Patience a little longer. Mr Theodore Meyer also called respecting his Passports; but I have not been able to obtain any for him. He will call again to-morrow Morning.— After dinner I took Charles with me to walk in the Summer-Gardens— Mrs Adams, with Mr and Mrs Smith paid an Evening visit to Countess Colombi’s. There they first heard the news of a great victory obtained by the Emperor Alexander in person, with Count Wittgenstein commanding under him, over the French commanded by the Emperor Napoleon, on the second day of this Month at Lutzen, near Leipzig a place already celebrated by the Battle in which Gustavus-Adolphus lost his life.— There is to be a Te Deum for it to-morrow at the Palace—15000 French killed—16 pieces of Cannon taken— No Prisoners— No Quarter given. The account came by a Courier, about 4 this afternoon— Princess Amelia of Baden announced it in a Note to Miss Bode, who was with her Sister—and the particulars were in a Note to Mr Zea.— Prince Kutuzoff of Smolensk, died at Bunzlau the 28th: of April.

13. I received this morning the notice for the Te Deum at the Imperial Chapel, for the victory obtained by the Russian imperial troops commanded by Count Wittgenstein, in presence of the Emperor Alexander, near the borough of Lutzen, over the French army commanded by the Emperor Napoleon— At half past twelve I went with Mr Smith to the Palace— The Te Deum began soon after— Scarcely any details of the Victory were given. We were told that the Emperor Alexander actually commanded; was on the field, and twice rallied the troops. But that he chose to have the Te Deum at the Chapel and not at the Kazan Church, and also chose to have it said that Wittgenstein commanded, from his personal modesty, and to avoid all appearance of ostentation. It was supposed the loss of men, was about equal on both sides; but fell most heavily on the Prussians, who are not even mentioned in the account read by the War Minister Gortschakoff before the Te Deum.
Count Maistre and Baron Blome, were the only other foreign Ministers present—the Duke de Serra-Capriola, Count Lowenhielm and the Chevalier Bardaxi-Azara, being confined at home by sickness— The Ceremony was short. On coming out I asked Mr Gourieff when I could call upon him, and he appointed the day after to-morrow, at 11. in the morning.— After dinner I went with Mrs Smith and Charles to the Catherinenhoff procession of Carriages; which was very much crowded; but where there were very few handsome Equipages— It was almost ten at Night when we came home— Charles lost great part of his lesson.

14. A late hour in the Evening, naturally produces a late morning hour. It was nearly seven this morning when I rose— My morning walk was short, and I had none in the Evening. Miss Frederica Bode had engaged to dine with us, but did not come— Mr Forbes dined with us. Mr Harris came in early in the Evening, and passed an hour or two with us. I finished reading the first Volume of Malthus. His observations upon the checks to population in England, Scotland, and Ireland seem to labour under a bias of unwillingness to apply his own principles to them in their fullest extent— Indeed I do not see how to escape from the inference from his premises that neither War, nor Pestilence, can at all affect the population, where the means of subsistence surpass the numbers of people to be fed. It appears irresistibly to follow from his premises, that wherever there is food, the principle of Population will always supply the mouth to consume it; and that nothing but famine can reduce the numbers of People in any Country— Yet he does often admit that the population of European Nations is diminished by War and by sickness— He allows it in a special manner with respect to France—

15. I called on Mr. Gourieff at 11. O’Clock this morning, the time appointed by him, and reminding him of my application, two Months since, in behalf of Mr Redwood, mentioned his anxiety to obtain an answer; he being desirous to return to America, and detained here only to await the decision of this affair. Mr Gourieff told me that it was before the Committee of Ministers; he took a minute of it, and promised to press the decision as speedily as possible.— I gave the rest of the morning to Charles’s lesson and to the English Newspapers sent me by Mr Harris— After dinner I walked in the Summer Gardens and afterwards on the Boulevard with Mr Lewis whom I met walking there— The Evening was uncommonly mild and beautiful— On my return home I found Miss Frederica Bode, with the Ladies— She soon went away— No details yet of the Emperor Alexander’s victory, but it is confirmed by the Berlin Gazette of 4. May. Mr Raimbert called upon me yesterday morning, and said that before the late battle, there had been an affair between the Viceroy of Italy and Count Wittgenstein of which no account has been published here.

16. Took Charles out to walk with me before Breakfast— We went into the Roman Catholic Church, but it was too early for the service. I read prayers for the fourth Sunday after Easter, and Sterne’s sermon upon the delays of divine retribution for evil: with a double text— One from Ecclesiasticus, and the other from St: Paul to the Romans— He begins by telling his hearer to take either as he likes it, that he will get nothing by the bargain— Besides this unseasonable joke, my wife remarked that there was a great inconsistency of argument between this discourse, and that upon the abuses of Conscience— I believe they cannot be reconciled— Here he speaks of Conscience as an infallible, and incorruptible Censor, and there he strenuously urges both its fallibility and corruptibility.— I likewise read the Capucin Joly’s letter upon the marches and stations of the Israelites from their departure out of the land of Egypt, untill they came to the passage of the Jordan— Much of it is conjectural; but it locates the mountain’s Sinaï, Horeb, Hor, Nebo and Pisgah, and several Cities. It discriminates between the mountain and the rock of Horeb, which last is said to be yet extant, and to bear evident marks though now dry of having poured forth water of yore— I compared the description with the map. The whole family dined at Mr Harris’s— Messrs: Raimbert and Montréal, Beresford, Lewis and Slade dined there— We also passed the Evening there untill 10— Just before we came away, Mr Laval sent in a verbal message— A Courier from the Grand Duke Constantine arrived about Noon, with a complete confirmation, and more than Confirmation of the Emperor’s victory at Lutzen— Instead of 150000 frenchmen slain 25000, instead of 16 Cannon 36 taken; and Wittgenstein in full pursuit of the fugitives— The Emperor had returned to Dresden, where the Emperor of Austria, and the king of Saxony were to meet him. Mr Beresford gave me a dirge written by him, and set to music by Mr Florio, and he also shewed me in manuscript two other amatory songs of his own writing— He had preached this morning, at the English Church, a Sermon upon preparation for death, with an application to the decease of Dr Pitt— Mr Beresford’s poetry did not much charm me— Another subject absorbed too fully my thoughts— Indeed I have within a few years lost almost the relish for good poetry. It struck me as strange to find a clergyman at least 70 years of age, consulting me upon the construction of verses about love-sickness, latent faults, and worth that [“]steals us from ourselves away.”— I grow cold as age advances.

17. After a sleepless Night, I rose at five, and took a short walk before Breakfast— Much of the day was occupied in settling my monthly accounts— After dinner, I rode with Charles to Kammenoi-Ostroff, and there walked half an hour— I closed the day at Nine in the Evening, while it was yet day-light— Mr Lewis passed the Evening here.— The trees are just turning green.

18. I walked this morning in the Summer Garden— The shrubs and small trees are assuming their verdure; but the old Elms, do not yet shew a leaf— I had a morning visit from Mr Harris— Neither of the Gazettes have yet published any details of the great Victory at Lützen; which occasions rumours to be in circulation that it was an equivocal victory— The usual custom here of announcing Victories which are sometimes real defeats always gives rise to strong suspicions in public, and to many adverse rumours, when the particulars are delayed. As this is beyond all comparison the most important of the victories that the Russians have gained in the present War, the impatience of the public is proportionably excited to learn the particulars— I suppose them to be delayed only to connect them with some decisive and important result— After dinner I rode with Charles to Catherinenhoff, and there walked about an hour.

19. Another sleepless Night, the cause of which was not so discernible, to myself, as the other Night. Took Charles with me to walk, and to see a regiment of soldiers exercising in front of the Winter Palace. Countess Colombi visited Mrs Adams before dinner— She had heard rumours of news from the Army less advantageous than those of last week, and spoke of the arrival of a Courier yesterday in which we afterwards found that she was misinformed— After dinner I walked in the Summer-Gardens; met Mr Slade, and afterwards Mr Lewis, and Mr Redwood— Mrs Adams walked with Charles to the Quay, and I returned with them. On our return home I found Mr Harris— His news, directly from General Armfeldt was that the victory at Lutzen not having been quite so decisive as had been expected the Emperor Alexander was at Dresden, sending on 150,000 men to fight one which would be completely so. The Courier with the news is hourly expected: but there was none arrived yesterday.— Mr Lewis and Mr Redwood took tea, and spent the Evening here.— I read several Chapters in the second volume of Malthus.

20. Miss Frederica Bode paid a visit to Mrs Adams this Evening. There was a Courier from the Emperor the day before yesterday, but he brought nothing new from the army— The victory at Lutzen is unquestionable, but it did not supersede the necessity of another the news of which is expected every moment. The alliance with Austria is certain.— I went out with Charles to Catherinenhoff and walked there, after dinner. I wish to give him as often as possible the benefit of Country air.— I read further in the second Volume of Malthus. His observations upon the systems of Equality are perfectly conclusive, and he has demolished the Babels of Condorcet and Godwin, to their uttermost foundations. His style is clear and forcible, but plain and almost dry— His manner generally grave, candid, moderate, and remarkable for its urbanity— He treats Godwin, and the memory of Condorcet with great gentleness, and keeps his temper always cool in a discussion, upon which others have been too apt to indulge their Passions— There is one instance of ridicule pointed at Condorcet, in the allusion to the crossing of the Bickerstaff breed, and several home thrusts in the reply to Godwin; but he handles them both as the king of Brobdignag handled Captain Gulliver— He has such a crushing power of argument over them that they can give him no occasion for emotion of temper—the Chapter on Emigration and that on the Poor Laws are highly important, and expose the erroneous policy of all the European Governments on these subjects— His deductions are so obvious and so irresistible, that it is astonishing they had so long escaped the attention of political writers, and of Statesmen.

21. Charles walked out with me before Breakfast. I had a long morning visit from Mr Harris— Count Wittgenstein’s Report to the Emperor of the Battle at Lützen, was at length published this day, in the Gazettes. It leaves yet much to be told. The victory hitherto appears to have consisted merely in maintaining possession of the field of Battle. Miss Frederica Bode dined with us; she said a Feld-jäger had arrived this morning from the Army, but she believed he had brought no News— I saw him arrive at the door of the Palace. A remarkable omission in Wittgenstein’s Report is that it has no date of place, and that it still remains generally unknown where the Russian and Prussian Head-Quarters were, after the Battle— We all went this Evening to the German Theatre, and saw King Theodore at Venice, with Paësiello’s music— It was very badly performed

22. The morning was fair and I walked— There was a steady rain all the remainder of the day. We all excepting Charles dined with Mr Lewis. Mr and Mrs Krehmer, Mr J. W. Smith, Mr Redwood and Mr Fisher were the rest of the company.— Dr: Beresford came in after dinner— Mr and Mrs Krehmer soon went away to attend the wedding of Miss Thieringk, Mrs Peter Severin’s sister— The remainder of us stayed untill 10 in the Evening. Mr J. W. Smith is a collector of Coins and Medals, of which he had several with him which he shewed us— Cromwell’s guinea, which belongs to Mr Severin— An unquestionable silver coin struck during his government, and with his effigy; a medal struck in his honour, upon his death; a Half-crown of Charles 2 well executed, and a Dutch Daalder with the sword sheathed,
and inverted, as he is informed at the express requisition of Louis 14, who had taken offence, at a naked sword stamped on the previous dutch Coins. I had some conversation upon literary subjects with Dr Beresford— Mr Krehmer’s was political and less agreeable.

23. Mrs: Adams was very unwell—confined the greatest part of the day to her bed— I walked through the Summer Gardens this morning, and with Charles at Catherinenhoff after dinner— I read prayers for the fifth Sunday after Easter, and Sterne’s Sermon upon trust in God; which is altogether serious— There is a passage of it towards the close, which is almost a repetition of one in a former Sermon of the collection— I also read two letters of father Joly, on the order of march observed by the Israelites in the desert, and on the Tabernacle of the Congregation, the Ark of the Covenant, the Altars of Burnt-offering and of incense, the table of shew-bread, and the brazen laver for the priests to wash in. And part of a letter on the sacrifices.— I wrote very little.

24. Mr J. W. Smith called upon me this morning, and brought with him to shew me the collection of Russian and other Coins that he has lately purchased— I looked over the Russian with him, and he left the rest with me.— I received letters from my father, mother, brother, and from Doctor Waterhouse, of the close of February and beginning of March. I rode out after dinner with Charles to Kammenoi-Ostrof, we found the bridge over to the island up; that from the Palace to the Strogonoff Garden is not yet finished. Returning home we stop’d and paid a short visit to Mr Raimbert and Mr Montreal— Mr Raimbert appeared to be quite unwell.

25. Took Charles to walk with me this morning, and we saw a Regiment of soldiers exercising before the Winter Palace.— After dinner I rode out with him to the Narishkin Garden, round which we walked. On returning home I found Mr Harris, and Mr Lewis— They had the news of a declaration of War by Austria against France. I read one or two Chapters in the second Volume of Malthus.

26. Mr J. W. Smith called upon me, and brought me the remainder of his Collection of Coins and Medals— I had not had time to look over those he had left with me before— He now left them all with me.— He informed me of his intention to go in about three weeks to England; and that he proposed to go as far as Stockholm with Mr Calhoun.— Mr Harris sent me the French, and German Translations of the Report of the Committee of H.R.U.S. and the rough draft of the Translation of the President’s message. He afterwards called and told me that he had been unable to procure a Russian Translation of these Papers.— I examined the corrected Copy of the French Report of the Committee, and the draft of the President’s Message— After dinner I rode out with Charles to the 8th: Verst on the Czarsko-Zelo road, and we walked there about half an hour— His health is not firm. My own is imperfect— Early hours, hard beds, temperance of diet, constant exercise, and fresh air, all which are so strongly and so universally recommended by the physicians to preserve health, are not sufficient here either for his or mine. We both suffer by the Climate; and I have other causes operating upon me.

27. I took Charles to walk this morning in the Summer Gardens and after dinner rode with him over the Summer-garden and Wyburg road Bridges, which are just restored, to the Strogonoff Garden where we proposed to walk, but were overtaken by rain, and obliged to return. Miss Frederica Bode dined with us, and Mrs Adams and Mrs Smith spent the Evening at Countess Colombi’s. I sent back to Mr Harris the French Translation of the President’s Message to Congress recommending the Declaration of War, and I gave two hours to the inspection of a part of the collection of medals and Coins left with me by Mr J. W. Smith. They are chiefly German and Italian, with a very few French, Spanish and English— The Venitian, and Papal coins of which there are many, I had never before seen— I read two or three Chapters of Malthus, making the application of his arguments and facts— The Chapter upon Moral Restraint considers celibacy as one of the most important of human virtues— Meaning celibacy with a strict observance of chastity, and so far as it is dictated by the inability to support a family.— His fundamental position that the natural increase of population is in a geometrical ratio, while the increase of food can only be in arithmetical proportion, is apparently incontrovertible— Many of his inferences are far from pleasing in contemplation, but I know not how to escape from them— It seems indeed that there are inferences, which he chooses himself to keep out of sight. For Countries fully peopled, War can have not the slightest tendency to diminish the population; and monastic institutions, devoted to the improvement of Agriculture must be wise, humane, and patriotic.— Dr: Beresford sent me a volume of Jortin’s remarks on Ecclesiastical History.

28. I had morning visits from Mr Montreal, Mr Harris, and Mr Lewis. There has been no official publication of military events, since the Battle at Lutzen, and the consequence is that innumerable rumours of every description are in circulation, upon none of which any dependence is to be placed. A retreat of the Russian and Prussian Armies, followed, immediately after the Battle of Lutzen, and the official silence observed since that time has occasioned some disappointment and uneasiness in the public mind— Vague and groundless reports of defeat and disaster have been whispered about, and other reports of success and victory have been spread abroad to counteract them. Mr Lewis informed me of news from England that the U.S. Sloop of War Hornet had sunk an English Sloop of War of superior force called the Peacock.— Mr Bardaxi the Spanish Minister sent me a packet received by Courier from Stockholm. It was from Mr Speyer, with one from Mr Warden at Paris, enclosing one from the Secretary of State of 30. November, with two pamphlets of public documents. After dinner I rode out with Charles to Krasna-Kabak, and after returning home walked alone on the Boulevard— Countess Colombi with her two Sisters, Miss Carnerero, Mr Forbes, and Mr Harris were here at tea, and the Evening, but did not stay to Supper.

29. Mr. Montreal called on me this morning— They have received a letter from their Correspondent at Hamburg, without signature, saying that things had changed, and requesting them not to send any more letters, and to ask their brother to send none too— He thought it signified that the French had again occupied the City; but in that case the communication would have been stopped, and the Post would not have brought the letter. Dr: Beresford, and Messrs: Montreal, Lewis, Redwood, and J. W. Smith dined with us. I had invited Mr Harris and Mr Fisher, but they were engaged— Mr Lewis had received a letter from Mr Norman at Berlin dated the 16th: of this Month, stating the People there to be in great alarm from the French, and that a Battle was hourly expected. About 3. O’Clock in the afternoon I saw a Courier pass before my windows, accompanied by a Cossack, the signal of good news— Within half an hour afterwards a second Courier passed, accompanied in the same manner— We concluded that they brought at least Accounts of another Victory.— Messrs: Lewis, Redwood and Smith passed the Evening with us, and the Ladies had Cards.— I read little in Malthus, and wrote Nothing.

30. I read prayers for the Sunday after ascension day, and Sterne’s Sermon, upon Murder. I suppose it to have been occasional, for he speaks in it of a criminal then lately executed for that crime. He also says that he proposes the ensuing Sunday to treat separately the subject of Suicide— But that Sermon is not published. The only peculiarity in this discourse marking the character of the author, is that he includes Quack Doctors, and the venders of quack medicines under the denomination of murderers— I also read several letters of Father Joly, on the Sacrifices, and Priests of the Hebrews, and on the Geography of the Land of Canaan— Miss Frederica Bode dined with us, and gave us the news of a great victory, atchieved by General Barclai de Tolli, brought by a Courier this day—those of yesterday she says brought nothing important. I walked after dinner with Charles to the Summer-Garden Bridge; over it, and afterwards in the Garden— There was some Company there, and no small number of Officers with one leg, and with arms in slings; the wrecks and tatters of the last year’s campaign.

31. I took Charles with me to walk this morning before Breakfast, and we saw the Parade before the Winter Palace, of half a Regiment, about six hundred men— They exercise every Morning there at 9 O’Clock, and during the remainder of the day, form the several guards at the Palace and in its vicinity.— After dinner the Curate of the Catholic Church Alexander de Penguilli called upon me, to acknowledge his signature to a Certificate of nativity for a young woman which Countess Colombi had requested me to authenticate— As soon as he had made his acknowledgment he began to entertain me with his own history, and his hatred of le Sieur Bonaparte— There was no man he said who more heartily wished that le Sieur Bonaparte might be beaten than he did— And his wish was to see his own legitimate king restored to the throne of his ancestors— Observing that I expressed no concurrence in his wishes, he added that perhaps he was indiscreet— He was a Bas-Breton, and they were notorious for speaking their minds openly. He had been before the French Revolution Curate at Quimper-Corentin on the road to Brest, and had received at his house the Emperor Paul, and the present Empress Mother when they were travelling as Count and Countess du Nord.— In the midst of the French Revolution, when Paul came to the throne, he the Abbé disgusted with what was doing in France, had written to Paul reminding him of the former occasion, when he had received him, and expressing his wish to come here— Paul answered him
that he perfectly recollected their acquaintance at Quimper-Corentin, and invited him immediately to come here; which he accordingly did— He was presented to Paul, who asked him what he could do for him— He was advised by some of his friends to ask for lands, and peasants, or a pension; but this he declined— He said that in France he had been a Curate, and his wish was to exercise the same profession here— Immediately upon which Paul issued an Ukase appointing him Curate of the Catholic Church— Six Months after, Paul gave the Church to the Jesuits—since which time he had lived there with them, though he was not himself a Jesuit, but a secular Priest— I told him I was acquainted with the father General; of whom he spoke in terms of great esteem— He appeared much inclined to discourse upon Politics, and repeated his hopes that the Sieur Bonaparte would certainly be put down, now that Austria had declared herself on the side of Russia— Mr Harris & Mr Lewis were here in the Evening, with news from England, and from America— Mr Daschkoff has made the offer of the Emperor of Russia’s Mediation between the United-States and Great-Britain, which was immediately accepted by the President.— The Account of the Hornet’s having sunk the Peacock is confirmed— The Bulletin of General Barclai de Tolli’s victory is published— It must have been part of a more general Action, of which the result and details are expected.

Day. There is more irregularity in the hours of rising and of retiring at Night, than the preceding Months— The former have varied between 4 and 7—and the latter between 9 and 12. The average has been from 10 to 5.— I read and write from the time of rising untill 8. then walk an hour or more— Breakfast between 9 and 10. Give Charles his lesson untill 2. Read or write letters untill 5. the hour of dinner.— After dinner I ride out of town, and walk, or walk in the City two or three hours— Very little interruption by visits made or received; and very little intercourse with Company abroad or at home— I teach Charles to read, write and cypher— His writing Master attends him besides twice a week. His progress is still very slow.
